Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Eliminating the Energy Efficiency Barrier of Reconfigurable Architectures for Diverse Signal Processing in Mobile Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to cohesively use coarse-grained reconfigurable devices and highly-scalable non-volatile memory technologies to fundamentally improve energy efficiency in future mobile devices. The new device architecture provides the capability to dynamically exploit significant run-time computational workload variation and large algorithm design freedom inherent in most signal processing tasks, effectively enabling just-enough computation. The approach embraces the memory-intensive and time-varying nature of many signal processing tasks, which can be leveraged to reduce overall system energy consumption. In addition, these approaches make it feasible to apply aggressive run-time power management on reconfigurable architectures to minimize static energy consumption. To fully evaluate the potential of these new opportunities, a comprehensive design methodology including circuits, architectures, compiler, and run-time system is used.

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this research lies in the cohesive integration and use of a coarse-grained reconfigurable device which includes interfaces to high-density non-volatile memory technology. This interface is exploited at the system level to dynamically adapt computation-intensive signal processing applications for significant energy savings.

Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this project are: 1) enhancement to graduate curricula in embedded systems and integrated circuit design, 2) application of the new technologies in the NSF-sponsored Engineering Research Center for Collaborative and Adaptive Sensing of the Atmosphere (CASA), 3) research infrastructure dissemination for education and training, and 4) outreach to high school students. The proposed architecture will enable future mobile devices to continue to track their historic performance and functionality scaling by supporting energy efficiency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has led to the development of a novel computing device that is well-suited for signal processing applications associated with communications and video processing. The device is based on multiple small processing elements (PEs) which can handle large amounts of data in parallel. The function of each PE is determined by a set of instructions stored in nearby data storage (MRAM). Processing elements are interconnected with a network-on-chip (NoC). Unlike current microprocessors which typically must be restarted each time power is applied to the system, our device is non-volatile which allows for immediate system start up. The application performed by the device can be easily updated in response to changing application parameters such as communication channel noise or image quality. A complete computing system has been developed as part of this project including circuits, applications, and software to map the applications to the processing elements. We have validated the new computing device using simulation and in-circuit testing. It is shown that our device can reduce system power consumption by up to 30% versus a computing device which does not allow frequent updates based on application parameters.

In this project, it also has been shown that microprocessors performing signal processing operations should include a wide variety of computing hardware that can used at different times. For example, when power consumption is less of an issue, a more complex version of the hardware can be used to complete operations more quickly. If power is constrained, a less complex version of the hardware can automatically be used. Experimentation has shown that power consumption can be reduced by about 20% using this approach and performance can be improved by about 10%.

The project has provided significant broader impacts. Two masters-level and five doctoral-level students have worked on this project. Three of the students are now employed in the digital electronics sector in the US. Material from the research has been integrated into several graduate and undergraduate courses at the University of Massachusetts. Source code from the project has been made available to the research community at large and has been used in a research project at the University of Hong Kong.
